questiontext.text:
Exercise

Decide which of the following pairs of events (\(A\) and \(B\)) arising from the experiments described are independent.

  1. One card is drawn from each of two packs.
    \(A=\) a red card is drawn from pack \(1\).
    \(B=\) a picture card is drawn from pack \(2\).
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[1]]
  2. A manufacture of cutting tools sources synthetic diamonds from two laboratories:
    \(A=\) the quality of the diamonds sourced from lab A meet the required specifications.
    \(B=\) the quality of the diamonds sourced from lab B meet the required specifications.
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[1]]
  3. Two boxes contains 20 nuts each, some have a metric thread, some have a British Standard Fine (BSF) threads and some have a British Standard Whitworth (BSW) thread. A nut is picked out of each box.
    \(A=\) a nut picked out of the first box is BSF.
    \(B=\) a nut picked out of the second box is metric.
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[1]]
  4. A box contains 20 nuts, some have a metric thread, some have a British Standard Fine (BSF) threads and some have British Standard Whitworth (BSW) thread. Two nuts are picked out of the box.
    \(A=\) first nut picked out of the box is BSF.
    \(B=\) second nut picked out of the box is metric.
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[2]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. \(P(A) = \frac{1}{4}\), \(P(B) = \frac{3}{13}\) and \(P(A \cap B) = \frac{3}{52}\). \(P(A\cap B) = P(A)P(B)\) so \(A\) and \(B\) are independent events.
  2. The process of growing diamonds by lab A does not influence how lab B grows diamonds, and visa versa. So events \(A\) and \(B\) are independent.
  3. The nuts are sampled from different boxes, so \(A\) and \(B\) are independent events.
  4. The nuts are sampled from the same box without replacement. The means that the probability that the second nut is metric will differ if the first sampled nut was or was not a metric nut. Therefore, events \(A\) and \(B\) are dependent.
